So the reason why I asked that question is because the way we're shaping up the AI features on hiver, there's three key pillars that hiver's AI can handle as of today.
And with our existing roadmap that's going to be, you know, ever evolving in the next couple of weeks, we're going to be launching one more AI feature as well.
So long story short, when it comes to the hiver AI feature set, you know, let me share my screen as well for like a quick visual and what I'm talking about.
So hiver is being useful for your team in two perspectives, right?
One is from an AI agent route and that's more along the operational lines, right?
Where AI can tag your conversations and categorize it.
You've got sentiment analysis as an additional aspect.
And then on the co, pilot route is where you get a more interactive AI, you know, version of hiver where you can effectively ask it questions.
It can draft responses for you that your team can just send in one click, things like that.
Okay.
All right.
So, yeah.

So when it comes to your incoming conversations, you did say that you'd want to categorize it, I know the existing versus new customers that's not data that hiver has access to readily as I'm sure you were.

So what you can instead, you know, consider is maybe having these AI tagging run as categories, you know, the type of issue, the nature of the request, things like that could all be categorized by hiver automatically, when you start receiving these emails?
Okay.
And whenever we start tagging after the conversation, what happens so we can assign it to different people or what can be done after the tagging has been completed?
That's a great question.
So, after the tagging has been completed, you have a whole range of options that you can choose from.
So let's say you're using AI to add the tags, what you can do is you can either say, hey, if the tag is one two three, right?
You can be very specific and you can be like, L, one escalation, urgent issue, and, you know, maybe L3 escalation, high priority, right?
So depending on the type of inquiry that you're receiving that the AI is capturing and tagging, you can do any number of actions.

It could be assigning it to one person in the team, assigning between a smaller group of people, adding a follower who gets updates but is not directly assigned to that email, sending a custom reply for that one situation, reassigning it to a different person sending a hiver notification, updating fields on hiver that you can have for additional mechanisms, all of this.
Wow.
Okay.
Yeah, that's good.
And another example that you said, right?
Which was, I want to figure out how to track replies and everything that's happening.
We've got an option for that.

So, if there's no reply from the client in three days and your team has done the last action which is send out a message to them, you can be like, hey hiver.
In this case, I want you to automate a follow up, going out again, situation specific scenario specific.
It can be like, hey, there we've written to you.

Okay.

And.

Which becomes another reply.
If you want hiver to do something else in terms of, you know, adding a note, triggering an approval flow, things like that can be done too.
It can't necessarily send a new email from scratch, but it can definitely bump up the same thread so that the quote is not lost.
The attachment always shows up in Gmail at the top.

So that way you're not going to lose out on the quote, but you still have the email bumped to the inbox, top of the inbox for the client.

When is it an urgent issue?

going to be very contextual, very driven based on the documents you've uploaded, the knowledge sources you've fed it, or even the knowledge base that you've built out on hiver that acts as your process, your vetting your approach basis, on which ask AI can generate a response.
